BLOG: Fire must not be afraid of the debate around the club that is going on, writes BT's Fire blogger Doddo.
07 Nov 2019, 10:01 by √òystein Vik
Fire hardship has been so long that I struggle with remembering the previous pregnancy period. It is as if there is no other edition than this speechless and poor version of Fire.
The strange thing is that Fire during this period has never experienced any collapse. Even against V√•lerenga, after being run over for almost a full lap, they managed to lift and take control of the match. There were no points this time around, but the players should be honored for the will and morale that they show in a phase where other teams had gone missing.
With the attitude that the players have, it is strange that Fire has not achieved more. The effort is impeccable.

Powerful reactions after Fire Post: - Ridiculous

Only one person is holding the key
But that's how it is to have adversity. Then luck is absent and flow is an unknown concept. The ground they run on becomes ever steeper and steeper, and the spiral in which they move only becomes more and more negative. Even the extracurricular becomes demanding. Be it ads, fan behavior or ticket sales. The club itches when they are communicating outwards, and whatever the coach does, he is pushed from all sides.
It turns into a rundown of everything the Fire Management does not want: weak economy, absent audiences and critical media outlets.
We all wonder what it takes to turn it around, and we all wish there was someone we could have done, but it's not. Only one person is holding the key. Only the trainer is in a position to take the necessary grips.
Since progress is awaiting, it is not the least bit strange that the coach's position is debated. That shouldn't surprise anyone, and at least no one in Fire. They should know better than anyone else what happens when results fail and the gap between supporters and club increases. Confidence is fragile like porcelain. Just ask Mons Ivar Mjelde, or Steinar Nilsen, or Rune Skarsfjord or Rikard Norling.

BALLSPARK BOY: Doddo records the Ballspark podcast with Erik Huseklepp, Anders Pamer and Mads B√∏yum every week.üì∑ Bj√∏rn Erik Larsen

Fire must be open and humble
Compared to everyone around them, the coach has a huge influence on what the team does. That is why we are trained with the Argus eyes. We tip our ears when he says something, and then we interpret and discuss what he says and does.
Such as the team take-off against V√•lerenga. Not everyone would have started with so many defensive players. Apart from Bamba, Jenssen and Barmen, there were defenders LAN pulled out of the hat. Few felt it was the right medicine for a team that scores few goals and is criticized for boring games.
It wasn't either. The starting student at Brann created just one small chance during the first forty-five.
It was far better when Fredrik Haugen made his entrance. With him on the team, Fire suddenly looked vital and strong again.
We have sorely missed such a creative force in the midfield. His re-entry into the team provides the basis for cautious optimism. Maybe it will be a long-awaited victory against Odd for the Fire's hard-fought players?
In the meantime, Fire must be open and humble. My recommendation is to not be afraid of the debate going on. It is inevitable in adversity.
Neither should they make up the reality or call critical supporters of surp pumps. Then they insult half the city.
